newsitem.title: USA: Georgia Senate approves natural gas deregulation.
newsitem.headline: Georgia Senate approves natural gas deregulation.

text.p: Georgia's Senate has approved a bill to deregulate the state's natural gas industry.
The proposal passed 51-0 in the Senate on Tuesday and now heads to the House.

The measure would dismantle the near-monopoly that Atlanta Gas Light Co has on gas supply and delivery in Georgia. About 75 percent of all natural gas consumed in Gainesville passes thorugh the companies lines.
The only competing gas supply and delivery company in the state is United Cities Gas Co, which serves Columbus and Gainesville.

The bill would allow customers to buy gas from unregulated marketers, who would use Atlanta Gas Light lines to deliver it. The bill's sponsor, Sen. Sonny Perdue, D-Bonaire, said competition should prevent prices from rising much if at all.
In a phone interview Wednesday, Atlanta Gas spokesman Ross Willis praised the measure and agreed it would save money for customers.
"We would have to be complimentary of Senator Perdue for putting together legislation everybody supports," Willis said.

The bill was drafted by a committee made up of consumer advocates, regulators, customers, and Atlanta Gas and its potential competitors. The comittee was created after the Georgia General Assembly defeated a deregulation proposal that Atlanta Gas had supported last year.

Under the new bill, deregulation would begin when one-third of the residential market is served by at least five gas marketing companeis, so long as companies owned by Atlanta Gas do not hold more than 18 percent.

When marketers gain that one-third share, the state's Public Service Commission would allocate the remaining two-thirds of the market in the same proportion as companies gained in the first third. The commission would then stop setting prices.

The bill prevents gas marketers from "cherry-picking" the most profitable customers, the industrials, by limiting each one's share of the industrial market to the same share it holds in the residential and small business market.
The Public Service Commission would authorize companies to do business in Georgia, and would have the authority to step in and re-regulate the industry if competition fails to keep prices in check.
The bill exempts municipal gas companies.
